'''Blind John Davis''' (December 7, 1913 — October 12, 1985)<ref name="dead rock stars">[http://users.efortress.com/doc-rock/1980.html Dead Rock Stars Club based birth and death details] efortress.com</ref> was an [[African-American]], [[blues]], [[jazz]] and [[boogie-woogie]] [[pianist]] and [[singing|singer]].<ref name="Russell"/><ref name="cascade"/> He is best remembered for his recordings including "A Little Every Day" and "Everybody's Boogie".<ref name="dead rock stars"/>

==Biography==
Davis was born in [[Hattiesburg, Mississippi|Hattiesburg]], [[Mississippi]], but he relocated with his family to [[Chicago]] at the age of two.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p325/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Blind John Davis |author=O'Neal, Jim |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=February 9, 2010}}</ref>  Seven years later he had lost his sight. In his early years Davis backed [[Merline Johnson]], and by his mid-twenties he was a well known and reliable accompanying pianist. Between 1937 and 1942, Davis recorded with [[Big Bill Broonzy]], [[Sonny Boy Williamson I]], [[Tampa Red]], Merline Johnson, and others, playing on many recordings of that time. He also waxed several efforts of his own, using his own lightweight [[human voice|voice]].<ref name="Russell"/>

After playing on various earlier recording sessions with him, in the 1940s Davis teamed up with [[Lonnie Johnson (musician)|Lonnie Johnson]].<ref name="Russell 3">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues - From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition=
| publisher=Carlton Books Limited
| location= Dubai
| page= 41
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref> Recording later on his own, "No Mail Today" (1949) became a minor [[hit single|hit]] for Davis.<ref name="Russell"/> Most of [[Doctor Clayton]]'s later recordings featured Davis on [[piano]].<ref name="Russell 2">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues - From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition=
| publisher=Carlton Books Limited
| location= Dubai
| pages= 101–102
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref>

He toured [[Europe]] with Broonzy in 1952, the first blues pianist to do so. In later years Davis toured and recorded frequently in Europe, where he enjoyed a higher profile than in his homeland.<ref name="AMG"/>

In 1955 Davis' Chicago house burnt down in which he lost his wife and his collection of 1700 unique 78 rpm records with issued and unissued recordings.<ref>Olderen, Martin van, liner notes of OLCD 7003 ''The Incomparable Blind John Davis'' (1997)</ref>

Davis died in his adopted [[:wikt:hometown|hometown]] of Chicago, at the age of 71, in October 1985.
